awd_titl_txt: JSU-RISE:  Research Infrastructure and Student Development through the Chemical Design of Multifunctional Carbon Nanotubes
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
JSU’s HBCU-RISE grant (HRD-1137763), funded since 10/01/2011, has provided the necessary resources to train a plethora of students (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate) and establish faculty collaborations at JSU.  Our HBCU-RISE grant (JSU-RISE) has significantly enabled JSU’s chemistry department to significantly improve its nanoscience research infrastructure, capacity and capabilities due to strong interdisciplinary collaborations between JSU’s HBCU-RISE faculty members. The program supported a total of 3 research associates, 4 PhD students, 2 undergraduate students and 4 high school students.  Recently, Zhen Fan, who earned his PhD in 2014 from JSU, joined the Ohio State University as a Post-doctoral Research Associate.  Dr. Dinadayalane, after finishing his Research Associate position, is now an Associate Professor at the Department of Chemistry at Clark Atlanta University. Three other HBCU-RISE Fellows graduated with their PhDs in December, 2015 and are seeking postdoctoral or academic positions.  

The intellectual achievements during this funding period include a range of significant discoveries. During this funding period, we have published over 20 papers, which were fully or partially supported by HBCU-RISE, in high impact journals including Nature Publication Journals (Scientific Reports) and others (Chemical Soc. Rev., Chem. Sci., J. Phys. Chem. Lett., ACS Applied Material Science, Bioconjugated Chem., RSC Advances, Nanaoscale, Chem. Eur. J., J. Mater. Chem, J. Phys. Chem. C, Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys, Farday Discussion, Particle & Particle System Characterization, Chem. Phys. Lett, Analyst and others). Among the publications, more than 95% of the published papers involve graduate and/or undergraduate students. The development of multifunctional theranostic nanoplatforms, which are capable of targeted detection and destruction of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), has been published in Particle & Particle System Characterization (Particle & Particle System Characterization, 2014, 31, 357-364), and, the 3rd issue of this journal featured the aforementioned manuscript as the cover page.

The broader impact of the JSU-RISE project focuses on developing the required infrastructure for JSU to conduct cutting-edge nano-science research and education programs with a specific focus on involving undergraduate and graduate underrepresented minority (URM) African American students and women.  The success of this JSU-RISE program is due to the establishment of a robust infrastructure for the education, training and mentoring of minority students and postdoctoral fellows through formal courses, lecture series and laboratory rotations between RISE faculty members. Finally, the HBCU-RISE program is playing an important role in the larger framework of JSU’s research enterprise by promoting inter-departmental collaborations and quality research projects that provide excellent research training to the students working in the labs of engaged faculty members. JSU’s HBCU-RISE researchers are dedicated to improving access to science for diverse groups and to building a competent workforce of scientists and engineers.  Our HBCU-RISE educational programs provide training opportunities for JSU graduate students to learn sta...
por.por_txt_cntn:
JSUÆs HBCU-RISE grant (HRD-1137763), funded since 10/01/2011, has provided the necessary resources to train a plethora of students (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate) and establish faculty collaborations at JSU.  Our HBCU-RISE grant (JSU-RISE) has significantly enabled JSUÆs chemistry department to significantly improve its nanoscience research infrastructure, capacity and capabilities due to strong interdisciplinary collaborations between JSUÆs HBCU-RISE faculty members. The program supported a total of 3 research associates, 4 PhD students, 2 undergraduate students and 4 high school students.  Recently, Zhen Fan, who earned his PhD in 2014 from JSU, joined the Ohio State University as a Post-doctoral Research Associate.  Dr. Dinadayalane, after finishing his Research Associate position, is now an Associate Professor at the Department of Chemistry at Clark Atlanta University. Three other HBCU-RISE Fellows graduated with their PhDs in December, 2015 and are seeking postdoctoral or academic positions.  

The intellectual achievements during this funding period include a range of significant discoveries. During this funding period, we have published over 20 papers, which were fully or partially supported by HBCU-RISE, in high impact journals including Nature Publication Journals (Scientific Reports) and others (Chemical Soc. Rev., Chem. Sci., J. Phys. Chem. Lett., ACS Applied Material Science, Bioconjugated Chem., RSC Advances, Nanaoscale, Chem. Eur. J., J. Mater. Chem, J. Phys. Chem. C, Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys, Farday Discussion, Particle & Particle System Characterization, Chem. Phys. Lett, Analyst and others). Among the publications, more than 95% of the published papers involve graduate and/or undergraduate students. The development of multifunctional theranostic nanoplatforms, which are capable of targeted detection and destruction of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), has been published in Particle & Particle System Characterization (Particle & Particle System Characterization, 2014, 31, 357-364), and, the 3rd issue of this journal featured the aforementioned manuscript as the cover page.

The broader impact of the JSU-RISE project focuses on developing the required infrastructure for JSU to conduct cutting-edge nano-science research and education programs with a specific focus on involving undergraduate and graduate underrepresented minority (URM) African American students and women.  The success of this JSU-RISE program is due to the establishment of a robust infrastructure for the education, training and mentoring of minority students and postdoctoral fellows through formal courses, lecture series and laboratory rotations between RISE faculty members. Finally, the HBCU-RISE program is playing an important role in the larger framework of JSUÆs research enterprise by promoting inter-departmental collaborations and quality research projects that provide excellent research training to the students working in the labs of engaged faculty members. JSUÆs HBCU-RISE researchers are dedicated to improving access to science for diverse groups and to building a competent workforce of scientists and engineers.  Our HBCU-RISE educational programs provide training opportunities for JSU graduate students to learn state-of-the-art research at The Ohio State University (OSU) where our students took advantage of the tremendous opportunity to engage in high level nanoscience related research activities at OSU while also acquiring hands-on training on the state-of-the-art facilities at OSU. Our HBCU-RISE summer research program was arranged for minority K12 students during the summer of 2012, and these students were fully immersed and productive while performing nanotechnology research at JSU.  Our aims were to use outreach activities at local high schools and initiate a Nanoscience Education program to enhance the local studentsÆ scientific literacy.
